Core Course: New Skills in Economic Growth
Ray C. Rist WBI Evaluation Unit World Bank William A. Eckert Advisor Senior Evaluator (202) 458-5625 (202) 458-1584
Number 2 March 1998
Araujo, Jorge (Notation: The World Bank Institute was formerly called the Economic Development Institute (EDI), as reflected in some text)
A Core Course on New Skills in Economic Growth was held in Washington, D.C. from February 9 - 14, 1998. This was the first of four course sessions planned for presentation during calendar year 1998 by EDIMP. The primary goal of these course offerings is to strengthen participants' analytical and research skills in the field of economic growth, and to enhance their capabilities to provide sound analysis and policy advice for achieving equitable and sustainable growth. Fifty-one participants attended this course session, consisting mainly of economists and other key personnel from partner institutions in developing countries. The session was evaluated by the EDI Evaluation Unit using an end-of-course questionnaire. The questionnaire consisted of two main sections. One section asked participants to rate aspects of the course on the extent that the course met standard performance criteria. These performance criteria included the level and quality of support provided by course sponsors, the ability of presenters and appropriateness of course materials, and the degree to which participants felt they had received suitable training. The second main section asked participants to rate their levels of information or knowledge about topics covered in the course, before and after completing the course. This attempted to measure achievement through participant self-assessment. A 5-point Likert type scale that ranged from 1 = minimum to 5 = maximum was used to rate participant response for each item. Following is a summary of these evaluation results:
· Overall ratings for the course's performance in different areas were high. Given that the scale's theoretical mid-point is 3.0, the mean score for all items was above that point. This suggests that on all of the indicators assessed, including content and delivery, participants expressed a high level of satisfaction with the course.
· A key indicator of course performance is the question that asks participants if this course was a worthwhile use of their time. On this indicator, results were very favorable. Participant mean score was 4.35 out of 5.0. This was one of the highest ratings received in this evaluation.
· Highest course ratings were given to support functions. These included the accommodations and administrative support provided. Each of these received a mean score of 4.35 out of 5.0, among the highest scores received in this evaluation.
· Two items stand out for their relatively low mean scores. These were both related to policy issues. One was the extent participants felt they learned about new policies. The other was learning about the consequences of new policies. These areas may be worth reviewing in future offerings and consideration given to why they were not rated as highly as other items.
· Pre/post self-assessment learning questions show substantial gain for ll items. These items were selected as issues that the course attempted to impart to participants. This consistent gain suggests that participants felt they did learn what the course's designers anticipated they would learn.  · On three items, participants indicated that their pre-course knowledge was relatively low. Each of these areas had a mean score of at or very near 3.0. It may be worth directing additional course time towards these areas, given the relative paucity in information reported by participants. These items also registered some of the greatest gains between pre and post knowledge levels reported by participants.
· Pre-course mean scores were generally in the 3.0-range. This measure can serve as an indicator of how much participants felt they knew about a topic upon entering the course. Its value is that it attempts to assess this level of information only after the course was completed. A high score on the pre-test would suggest that this topic should be reviewed for its contribution to new information for participants. The findings from this course show that these scores were not high enough to suggest that participants felt they knew a great deal about any of the topics upon entering the course.
· The consistent gains in pre/post information reported by participants should be interpreted with caution. These gains were impressive and do reflect the belief by participants that they received a great deal from this course. However, this is not a valid measure of what was actually learned by participants. Future course offerings would benefit from developing and administering cognitively based questions capable of assessing what was truly learned by participants in the course, as opposed to what they feel they gained.
